choices.C: Ensure the preshared key on the hub-and-spoke router matches.
choices.D: Adjust the ip nhrp network-id command on the hub router.
choices.B: Correct the next hop server IP address on the spoke router.
choices.A: Permit UDP ports 500 and 4500 between the hub and spoke.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The network security engineer identified that the hub router cannot send traffic to the spoke router. Based on the provided output, which action resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Only B is left. 

A. Permit UDP ports 500 and 4500 between the hub and spoke. (Wrong Answer. We have an IPSEC SA.

B. Correct the next hop server IP address on the spoke router.
C. Ensure the preshared key on the hub-and-spoke router matches. (Wrong answer, we have an IPSEC SA)
D. Adjust the ip nhrp network-id command on the hub router. (Wrong answer, NETWORK-ID are locally significant.)
A is my guess, spoke already sent registration since Isakmp see's its remote address.

A. LDAPS is correct
https://community.cisco.com/t5/security-knowledge-base/password-management-with-ldap-vs-radius-for-vpn-users/ta-p/3147278

Selected Answer: A
https://community.cisco.com/t5/security-knowledge-base/password-management-with-ldap-vs-radius-for-vpn-users/ta-p/3147278

To meet the security requirements of forcing AnyConnect users to use complex passwords, warning users before their password expires, and allowing users to change their password during a remote access session, the authentication protocol that must be used is RADIUS (Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service). RADIUS is a widely used authentication protocol that provides centralized authentication, authorization, and accounting for remote access. It supports a variety of authentication methods, including the ability to enforce complex password policies and password expiration warnings. Additionally, RADIUS allows users to change their passwords during a remote access session, providing flexibility and convenience. On the other hand, LDAPS (LDAP over SSL/TLS) is a secure version of the LDAP protocol used for directory services. While LDAPS can provide secure authentication, it does not inherently include the ability to enforce complex passwords, password expiration warnings, or support password changes during a remote access session. Therefore, to meet the specified security requirements, the authentication protocol that must be used is RADIUS.

Selected Answer: A
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/asa/asa97/configuration/vpn/asa-97-vpn-config/vpn-groups.html

Which authentication protocol must be used to meet these requirements?

questions.question_text: An engineer is implementing a failover solution for a FlexVPN client site where ESP traffic to the primary FlexVPN server is blocked intermittently after tunnel establishment. This issue causes users at the branch site to lose access to the corporate network. The solution must quickly establish a tunnel and send traffic to the secondary FlexVPN server only during a failover event. Which action must the engineer take to implement this solution?

choices.A: Create one tunnel with peer statements to each server and use Dead Peer Detection to track the status or the primary server.
choices.B: Create two tunnels for each FlexVPN server and use the tunnel keepalive command to track the status of each FlexVPN server.
choices.C: Create one tunnel with peer statements to each server and use object tracking to track the status of the primary server.
choices.D: Create two tunnels for each FlexVPN server and use a dynamic routing protocol to track the status or each FlexVPN server.

choices.B: The new client image does not use the same major release as the current one.
choices.A: The XML profile is not configured correctly for the affected users.
choices.D: Client software updates are not supported with IKEv2.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
crypto ikev2 enable outside client-services port 443
which means when we enable client services they are done over port 443 ( ergo SSL)
although client services which I found only mention Group policy updates and not full software updates, so im a bit split

"D" seems to be the correct answer here. The problem that might prevent IKEv2 users from automatically downloading a new AnyConnect release when they connect to the Cisco ASA is that client software updates are not supported with IKEv2. Client software updates are a feature that allows the Cisco ASA to push new AnyConnect software releases to the connected clients automatically. However, this feature is only supported for SSL VPN connections and not for IKEv2 VPN connections. As per the given scenario, where IKEv2 is being used for one group of users and SSL for another group, the IKEv2 users will not have the capability to automatically download a new AnyConnect release when they connect. This is because client software updates are specifically designed for SSL VPN connections and are not supported with IKEv2. Therefore, the problem lies in the fact that client software updates are not supported with IKEv2, rather than the client services not being enabled.
answer is D

Answer correct is A
Answer A suggests that the XML profile may not be configured correctly for the affected users. The XML profile is a configuration file that can be used to customize the behavior of the AnyConnect client. It is possible that the XML profile for the IKEv2 users is not configured to allow automatic updates, or that it is pointing to an incorrect location for the new client image.
https://community.cisco.com/t5/vpn/anyconnect-with-ikev2/td-p/2478375
